Mike Clark wrote:
> On Jan 5, 2005, at 5:43 AM, Harald M. Muller wrote:
> 
> > when you last wrote a library (say of a few 100 classes) 
> and delivered
> > it to customers (internal, external), and you decided (what 
> I always 
> > do)
> > that you delivered it including all test cases and test 
> classes (i.e.
> > the complete test suite), did you then
> > a) include Javadoc for the testsuite classes
> > b) deliver a separate Javadoc for the testsuite classes
> > c) not deliver any Javadoc for the testsuite classes
> > ?
> 
> FWIW, I don't deliver JavaDoc for test classes.  I generally 
> don't put 
> JavaDoc tags in my test classes, so any generated JavaDoc 
> would simply 
> show the class and method names.  You get that same information when 
> you run the tests.

Sorry - probably I wasn't clear enough: I was not (only) talking about
TestCase classes, but *all* the classes making up a test suite. Most
libraries of today are extendible - in fact, they often provide only
interfaces without implementations. As an (not really good, but easily
available) example, take JDK's Runnable interface. Obviously, you would
have written a test with a concrete class implementing Runnable - at
least to test the Thread(Runnable) and Thread(Runnable, String), but
also SwingUtilities.invokeLater(Runnable) and others. These concrete
classes are therefore part of your test suite. My question somewhat
rephrased:
When this last happened to you,

a)/b) did you javadoc these classes - which might be interesting for the
API user as useful small examples? - 
a) in the Javadoc of the library (where they clutter up the "real API",
but are readily available)
b) in a separate Javadoc?

c) Or do you deliver the examples as code only and point the users to
some test/examples directory, without giving them Javadoc for those
classes?

Regards
Harald M. Mueller
